entry.title: Combined summary - [Pre-BIP Discussion] Bitcoin Node Repository Consensus-Policy Separation
entry.summary: Juan Alemán, a developer involved with Bitcoin since 2017, has raised concerns over the changes in version 30 defaults of the Bitcoin software, which diverge significantly from historical practices. He points out that these changes have led to discussions about a potential fork in the network, highlighting the influence of the "Official Reference Implementation" centralized node software repository on default policy in the network. Alemán suggests that this influence represents a form of centralization that could harm the network by introducing abrupt default policy changes. To address this issue, he proposes a structural change to the Bitcoin repository: separating consensus code from policy-based node distribution. Alemán's proposal includes renaming the bitcoin/bitcoin repository to bitcoin/bitcoin-core to focus solely on consensus rules, thus removing non-critical policies from its scope. This would turn it into a neutral base for all node implementations, emphasizing hardening and testing consensus without the distraction of policy issues. Additionally, he suggests creating a separate repository for the full-featured node client, starting with bitcoin/bitcoin-node as the foundational template. This repository would embed the consensus-focused bitcoin-core while including default policies recommended by current core developers. Alemán believes this approach will reduce the official repo's influence on default policy, aligning better with Bitcoin's decentralization principles. Despite the potential benefits, Alemán acknowledges drawbacks, such as breaking existing infrastructure tied to the original GitHub repository. However, he argues that the proposed bitcoin/bitcoin-node can serve as a direct replacement, mitigating significant disruptions. His proposal aims to offer a compromise where no party feels forced to comply, promoting a more neutral stance from the Official Reference Implementation repository. In response to Alemán's proposition, Greg Maxwell and Matt Corallo engage with the idea, suggesting that if Alemán sees value in this reorganization, nothing should stop him from pursuing it independently. Antoine Riard echoes the sentiment that there shouldn't be an "official" authority within the Bitcoin network, acknowledging the power dynamics at play but emphasizing the need for structural change to reflect the decentralized ethos of Bitcoin truly. Riard shares his success with libbitcoinkernel, showcasing the practical application of separating various components of the Bitcoin software, further illustrating the feasibility and potential benefits of Alemán's proposal.
